keyTakeAways: Tropical Storm Fengshen is approaching the Philippines, prompting thousands of evacuations from coastal areas, particularly on Catanduanes island.
The storm poses a risk of coastal flooding from 1.2-meter waves and strong winds up to 80 km/h, leading to government-ordered evacuations of high-risk zones.
Catanduanes, with a population of 270,000, is frequently the first landmass affected by Pacific cyclones due to its geographic location.
The Philippines is exposed to an average of 20 storms annually, with vulnerable, impoverished populations in disaster-prone areas.
Climate change is linked to increasing storm intensity, with scientists warning that storms are becoming more powerful due to global warming.
The country is still recovering from recent disasters, including deadly earthquakes and typhoons, which have already claimed dozens of lives and disrupted communities.

summaryOfNewsArticle: As Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches the Philippine coast, thousands of residents on the island of Catanduanes have evacuated due to risks of coastal flooding and strong winds. The storm is expected to pass near Catanduanes with gusts up to 80km/h and waves reaching 1.2 meters. This evacuation is part of a recurring drill, as Catanduanes is often the first landmass affected by Pacific cyclones. The Philippines faces frequent storms and earthquakes, with recent disasters including deadly quakes in Cebu and southern regions, and a prior typhoon, Ragasa, in September. Scientists warn that increasing storm intensity is linked to climate change, raising long-term concerns for disaster resilience in the region.
title: Thousands evacuate Philippine coast as Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches
